snippet.title: Hunter girls prepare for inaugural fixture
snippet.content:
IT WILL be a representative game with a difference for seven Hunter rugby union girls. Not only will sisters play alongside and against one another in Bathurst on Sunday, but the NSW Country versus NSW City under 17s fixture is the first of its kind.
RUGBY REPRESENTATIVES: Jorja Holden, Leilani Nathan, Zoe Holden, Lupe Ngatuvai, Nicole Nathan and Emma Bradford. Picture: Supplied The inaugural clash - a regular in the boys, men and senior women ranks - helps pave the way for junior females in the sport.
It comes as three Hunter players - Mollie Gray, Sarah Riordan and Katrina Barker - prepare to fly out with the Wallaroos for the World Cup in Ireland and follows last week's Youth Commonwealth Games rugby sevens gold medal for another Hunter trio - Hannah Southwell, Layne Morgan and Brydie Parker.
SISTERS: Zoe and Jorja Holden with their NSW City and NSW Country gear. Picture: Supplied This weekend sees Maitland duo Jorja and Zoe Holden go head-to-head for country and city respectively while Newcastle twins Leilani and Nicole Nathan line up together for the junior Corellas.
Maitland inside centre Lupe Ngatuvai, Newcastle lock Emma Bradford and prop Tia Cook of Raymond Terrace round out the gold and black contingent. They have all played sevens and 10-a-side with Hunter junior teams. This group is coached by Hunter Sports High School rugby coordinator Will Scully and former Australian men's sevens player Ross Duncan.
Hunter girls prepare for inaugural fixture
exit * TRIALS for the Newcastle Knights' inaugural Tarsha Gale Cup team will be held across the Hunter later this year following a boom schoolgirls gala day at Raymond Terrace last week. Around 500 girls converged at Lakeside Sporting Complex on Thursday, which doubled participation from last year's event, and organisers are hopeful many will take part in the Country Rugby League November Nines.
It will entail six weeks of competition at various venues for under 14s, under 16s and under 18s.
The oldest age group will double as selections for the Knights, who are set to participate in the second edition of the NSW under-18 girl's season in 2018.
Results wise from the Central Hunter Girls Rugby League Gala Day and Gloucester won the Caitlin Moran Open Secondary while Hunter Sports claimed both the Isabelle Kelly Under 16s and Kacey Drummond Cup for year 7-8.
* STILL on rugby league and Knights Knockout winners Warners Bay (under 16s), St Joseph's, Aberdenn (under 15s), St Mary's, Gateshead (under 14s) and St Joseph's, Lochinvar (under 13s) take to Whalan Reserve in western Sydney on Tuesday for the 73rd annual NSW All Schools carnival. Hunter Sports High will contest the elite section on Wednesday. The primary divisions were decided on Monday with St Mary's Scone beaten 6-0 by Regentville in the open A final.
* NEWCASTLE cricketer Josh Claridge has been named skipper of the Sydney Thunder country squad for this month's Under-17 State Challenge at Coffs Harbour.
Claridge will be joined by six fellow Newcastle players and another from Maitland for the NSW junior trial between August 18 and 20. Newcastle trio Mitchell Lole, Nathan Hillier and Toby Gray will also line up for the Sydney Thunder country team.
The Sydney Sixers country group includes another Newcastle treble Lewis Hextell, Luke Muddle and Glenn Winsor as well as Central North duo Will Fort and Jackson Gwynne. * THE inaugural Swim League finals will be held at Woy Woy next Sunday (August 13) with dual Olympian Thomas Fraser-Holmes to oversee proceedings.
This weekend's final round will determine the top four with the Lake Macquarie Wizards, Newcastle Royalty (5 points), Central Coast Heat and Hunter Valley Vipers (4) all jostling for positions. The Port Stephens Pirates (0) will miss out.
